title: Matthew Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is described as the son of David and the son of Abraham in Matthew 1?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:1 states that the book is about the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham.

questions.question: Who begat Isaac according to Matthew 1?
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:2 shows Abraham begat Isaac.

questions.question: Who was the father of Phares and Zara?
questions.correctAnswer: Judas
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:3 records that Judas begat Phares and Zara of Thamar.

questions.question: Who was the mother of Booz?
questions.correctAnswer: Rachab
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:5 identifies Booz as the son of Salmon and Rachab.

questions.question: Which king begat Solomon of her that had been the wife of Urias?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:6 states that David the king begat Solomon of her that had been the wife of Urias.

questions.question: How many generations were there from Abraham to David?
questions.correctAnswer: Fourteen
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:17 states there were fourteen generations from Abraham to David.

questions.question: What was Joseph's initial reaction upon finding Mary with child?
options: He was minded to put her away privily
questions.correctAnswer: He was minded to put her away privily
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:19 explains Joseph was minded to put Mary away privily because he was a just man and did not want to make her a public example.

questions.question: Who appeared to Joseph in a dream to explain Mary's pregnancy?
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of the Lord
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:20 states the angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream to explain the conception was of the Holy Ghost.

questions.question: What name was Joseph instructed to give to Mary's son?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:21 says Joseph was told to call the child Jesus because he shall save his people from their sins.

questions.question: Complete the prophecy quoted in Matthew 1:23: 'Behold, a virgin shall be with child, and shall bring forth a son, and they shall call his name ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: Emmanuel
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:23 states the son shall be called Emmanuel, meaning God with us.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 1 says Joseph was not willing to make Mary a public example.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:19 describes Joseph as a just man not willing to make Mary a public example.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 1, Mary and Joseph had no children before Jesus.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:25 states Joseph knew Mary not until she had brought forth her firstborn son Jesus.

questions.question: True or False: The genealogy in Matthew 1 includes people carried away to Babylon.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:11-12 mentions Jechonias and his brethren about the time they were carried away to Babylon and the genealogy continues after that.

questions.question: Complete the name in Matthew 1:16: 'And Jacob begat Joseph the husband of Mary, of whom was born ______, who is called Christ.'
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:16 clearly states Jesus was born of Mary, wife of Joseph.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Matthew 1:21: 'And she shall bring forth a son, and thou shalt call his name ______: for he shall save his people from their sins.'
questions.correctAnswer: JESUS
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:21 instructs the name JESUS for the child because he will save his people from their sins.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trust after learning unexpected news about their family. Based on Matthew 1, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God’s plan?
options: God’s plan unfolds through generations and is trustworthy
We must rely solely on our own understanding
Doubt is the only natural response to surprises
Family history is irrelevant to God’s purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God’s plan unfolds through generations and is trustworthy
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:1-17 shows God’s sovereign plan through the genealogy of Jesus, emphasizing trust in God’s unfolding purpose. Verses 1, 17 and 20 reveal God’s faithfulness through generations.

questions.question: How does the genealogy in Matthew 1 teach us about humility in our daily work and life?
options: God uses ordinary people and imperfect backgrounds to fulfill His promises
Only perfect ancestors matter in God’s plan
Genealogies are irrelevant to Christian humility
Success depends on personal merit alone
questions.correctAnswer: God uses ordinary people and imperfect backgrounds to fulfill His promises
questions.explanation: The genealogy includes imperfect figures like David and Rahab (Matthew 1:5-6), teaching humility by showing God’s grace working through ordinary human stories. Verses 3, 5, and 6 highlight this truth.

questions.question: A believer is uncertain about obeying God’s call in difficult circumstances. Based on Joseph’s example in Matthew 1, what should you advise?
options: Obedience to God requires faith and action despite uncertainty
Wait for perfect clarity before acting
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God requires faith and action despite uncertainty
questions.explanation: Joseph obeyed the angel’s command (Matthew 1:20, 24) despite his initial confusion, showing trust and prompt obedience. Verses 19, 20, 24 illustrate this principle.

questions.question: In terms of family life and parenting, what lesson does Matthew 1 offer about naming and identity?
options: Names carry spiritual and prophetic significance
Children’s names should be chosen randomly
Family names are only for tradition
questions.correctAnswer: Names carry spiritual and prophetic significance
questions.explanation: Joseph was instructed to name Jesus because the name had a mission—to save (Matthew 1:21) and was linked to prophecy (verse 23). This shows the importance of intentional naming.

questions.question: How does Matthew 1 teach about dealing with temptation and maintaining integrity?
options: Joseph chose to act justly and not expose Mary to public disgrace
Compromise is acceptable in tough situations
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph chose to act justly and not expose Mary to public disgrace
questions.explanation: Joseph’s decision to put Mary away quietly (Matthew 1:19) shows integrity and mercy, illustrating righteous conduct in testing times. Verses 19 and 20 support this.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 1, Jesus’ birth was a fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:22-23 explicitly states Jesus’ birth fulfilled the prophecy about a virgin bearing a son called Emmanuel, meaning God with us.

questions.question: How does Matthew 1 encourage believers to be witnesses for Christ in their daily lives?
options: By recognizing Jesus as Savior and sharing His story
By relying on others for evangelism
questions.correctAnswer: By recognizing Jesus as Savior and sharing His story
questions.explanation: The genealogy and birth narrative (Matthew 1:1-25) emphasize Jesus’ role as Savior, encouraging believers to share this good news. Verses 21 and 25 highlight His saving mission.

questions.question: A believer is facing trials and doubts. What encouragement about perseverance can you draw from Matthew 1?
options: God’s plan persists through generations and circumstances
Trials mean God has abandoned you
Give up when things get hard
Only immediate results prove God’s presence
questions.correctAnswer: God’s plan persists through generations and circumstances
questions.explanation: The genealogy (Matthew 1:1-17) shows God’s faithfulness through many generations, including exile, encouraging perseverance and trust. Verses 11, 12, and 17 are key here.

questions.question: True or False: Joseph knew Mary intimately before Jesus was born, according to Matthew 1.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:25 states Joseph did not know Mary until she had given birth, emphasizing obedience and purity before Jesus’ birth.

questions.question: What does Matthew 1 teach about faith and prayer when facing unexpected challenges in marriage?
options: Trusting God’s guidance and seeking His direction leads to peace
Making decisions without seeking God is best
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God’s guidance and seeking His direction leads to peace
questions.explanation: Joseph’s response to Mary’s pregnancy was prayerful and trusting after the angel’s message (Matthew 1:20, 24), showing the importance of faith in marriage challenges.

questions.question: How does Matthew 1 encourage believers to practice humility and contentment in their spiritual walk?
options: By reflecting on God’s use of imperfect people in His plan
questions.correctAnswer: By reflecting on God’s use of imperfect people in His plan
questions.explanation: The genealogy includes flawed ancestors such as David and others (Matthew 1:6, 11), teaching humility and contentment with God’s grace. Verses 6, 7, and 11 support this.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Joseph was described as a _______ man who did not want to expose Mary to public disgrace.
questions.correctAnswer: just
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:19 describes Joseph as a just man, showing his integrity and compassion toward Mary.

questions.question: How does the account of Jesus’ birth in Matthew 1 teach about God’s presence with His people?
options: Jesus is called Emmanuel, meaning God with us
God’s presence depends on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus is called Emmanuel, meaning God with us
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:23 identifies Jesus as Emmanuel, emphasizing God’s tangible presence among His people through Christ.

questions.question: A believer is reflecting on stewardship and generational blessing. What can Matthew 1 teach about God’s faithfulness through family heritage?
options: God’s blessings and promises extend through generations
Each generation is independent of God’s plan
questions.correctAnswer: God’s blessings and promises extend through generations
questions.explanation: The genealogy (Matthew 1:1-17) demonstrates God’s ongoing covenant through Abraham, David, and down to Jesus, showing generational faithfulness. Verses 1, 2, and 17 highlight this.

questions.question: How does Joseph’s response to the angel’s message in Matthew 1 serve as a model for Christian obedience and humility?
questions.correctAnswer: He obeyed immediately without hesitation
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:24 shows Joseph rising immediately and taking Mary as his wife, modeling prompt obedience and humility before God’s will.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 1.

questions.question: What is the significance of the genealogy being divided into three sets of fourteen generations in Matthew 1:17?
options: It symbolizes completeness and divine order
It reflects a historical error in genealogy
It is a random numerical grouping
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes completeness and divine order
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:17 presents the genealogy in three groups of fourteen generations, which many scholars believe symbolizes completeness and God's sovereign plan in history, reflecting Hebrew numerology and literary structure.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure is directly mentioned in Matthew 1:6 as the father of Solomon?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:6 states that Jesse begat David the king, and David begat Solomon, linking Jesus’ genealogy to King David as a fulfillment of messianic prophecy.

questions.question: The name 'Emmanuel' mentioned in Matthew 1:23 is interpreted as:
questions.correctAnswer: God with us
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:23 quotes Isaiah 7:14, explaining that Emmanuel means 'God with us,' emphasizing the divine presence incarnate in Jesus.

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of Joseph being described as a 'just man' in Matthew 1:19?
options: He was righteous but merciful, choosing to quietly divorce Mary
He was a strict enforcer of the law without compassion
He was a priest in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He was righteous but merciful, choosing to quietly divorce Mary
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:19 highlights Joseph’s righteousness and mercy by noting he did not want to publicly disgrace Mary, reflecting Jewish legal customs and his compassionate character.

questions.question: In Matthew 1:18, the phrase 'before they came together' most directly points to which theological concept?
questions.correctAnswer: Virgin birth
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:18 emphasizes that Mary was found to be with child by the Holy Ghost before marital relations, affirming the doctrine of the virgin birth.

questions.question: Which Old Testament prophet is implicitly referenced in Matthew 1:22-23 through the prophecy about the virgin birth?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:22-23 quotes Isaiah 7:14 regarding the virgin birth and the name Emmanuel, showing the fulfillment of Isaiah’s prophecy in Jesus.

questions.question: What is the significance of the genealogy starting with Abraham in Matthew 1:1?
options: It establishes Jesus' Jewish heritage and fulfillment of Abrahamic promises
It shows Jesus descended from Egyptian royalty
It traces Jesus' lineage to Greek philosophers
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes Jesus' Jewish heritage and fulfillment of Abrahamic promises
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:1 begins the genealogy with Abraham to emphasize Jesus as the fulfillment of God's promises to the patriarch and the Jewish people.

questions.question: How does the mention of women like Tamar, Rahab, and Ruth in the genealogy (Matthew 1:3-5) contribute to the theological message?
options: It highlights God's grace extending beyond traditional boundaries
It indicates the genealogy is incomplete
It shows Jesus’ lineage is purely royal
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights God's grace extending beyond traditional boundaries
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:3-5 includes women with complex backgrounds, illustrating God's inclusive grace and foreshadowing Jesus' mission to all people.

questions.question: What is the historical context of 'being carried away to Babylon' mentioned in Matthew 1:11-12?
options: The Babylonian exile of the Jewish people
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian exile of the Jewish people
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:11-12 situates Jesus’ genealogy around the Babylonian exile, a pivotal event that shaped Jewish identity and messianic expectations.

questions.question: Why does Matthew emphasize Joseph as 'the husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus' in Matthew 1:16?
options: To clarify Jesus' legal, not biological, descent from David
To suggest Joseph was Jesus’ biological father
To deny Mary’s role in Jesus’ birth
questions.correctAnswer: To clarify Jesus' legal, not biological, descent from David
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:16 underscores Joseph’s legal fatherhood, important for messianic claims of descent from David, despite the virgin birth.

questions.question: Which Greek term in Matthew 1:21 is used to describe Jesus' role as Savior, and what is its significance?
options: Sōtēr, meaning deliverer or savior who rescues from sin
questions.correctAnswer: Sōtēr, meaning deliverer or savior who rescues from sin
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:21 uses the Greek term 'Sōtēr' to describe Jesus' saving role, emphasizing deliverance from sin, a key theme in New Testament soteriology.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 1:25, Joseph had marital relations with Mary before Jesus was born.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:25 states Joseph 'knew her not till she had brought forth her firstborn son,' indicating no marital relations until after Jesus’ birth.

questions.question: How does Matthew 1:20’s reference to the 'angel of the Lord' appearing in a dream connect to Old Testament theophanies?
options: It parallels divine communication methods seen in dreams throughout Hebrew Scriptures
It is unique and not found in Old Testament tradition
It contradicts Old Testament angelic appearances
It indicates an angelic messenger from Greek mythology
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels divine communication methods seen in dreams throughout Hebrew Scriptures
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:20’s angelic dream visit aligns with Old Testament examples (e.g., Joseph son of Jacob, Daniel) where God communicates through dreams.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'Jesus, who is called Christ' in Matthew 1:16 imply about Jesus' identity?
options: He is the promised Messiah or Anointed One
He is a common Jewish teacher
questions.correctAnswer: He is the promised Messiah or Anointed One
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:16 identifies Jesus as the 'Christ,' the Greek equivalent of Messiah, affirming his role as the anointed savior expected in Jewish tradition.

questions.question: Why does Matthew include the mention of Jechonias and his brethren 'about the time they were carried away to Babylon' in Matthew 1:11?
options: To mark a significant historical and theological break in Jewish history
To highlight the Greek influence on Judaism
questions.correctAnswer: To mark a significant historical and theological break in Jewish history
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:11 situates the genealogy within the context of the Babylonian exile, underscoring the disruption and later restoration of Israel’s hope in the Messiah.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What theological significance is conveyed by Matthew 1:1 referring to Jesus as 'the son of David, the son of Abraham'?
options: It affirms Jesus' legal and royal lineage fulfilling Messianic prophecy
It emphasizes Jesus' divine nature as God the Father
It denies Jesus' humanity and earthly ancestry
It focuses solely on Jesus' priestly role
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms Jesus' legal and royal lineage fulfilling Messianic prophecy
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:1 establishes Jesus' genealogy linking Him to David and Abraham, fulfilling Old Testament promises (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Jeremiah 23:5; Genesis 12:3; Romans 1:3). This affirms Jesus as the promised Messiah from David's royal line and Abraham's covenantal seed.

questions.question: According to Matthew 1:17, how many generations are there from Abraham to David, and what theological significance does this numerical pattern hold?
options: Fourteen generations, symbolizing divine completeness and God's providential plan
Twelve generations, representing the twelve tribes of Israel
Ten generations, symbolizing completeness of law
questions.correctAnswer: Fourteen generations, symbolizing divine completeness and God's providential plan
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:17 highlights three sets of fourteen generations marking God's sovereign timing in history, reflecting completeness (Genesis 5; Revelation 21:6; Psalm 12:6; Galatians 4:4). The number fourteen also connects to David’s name numerically, emphasizing Jesus' royal messianic identity.

questions.question: What role does the Holy Spirit play in the conception of Jesus according to Matthew 1:18-20?
options: The Holy Spirit miraculously causes the virgin birth, affirming Jesus' divine origin
The Holy Spirit is not mentioned in Jesus’ conception
The Holy Spirit inspires Mary to conceive naturally
The Holy Spirit descends only after Jesus’ birth
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit miraculously causes the virgin birth, affirming Jesus' divine origin
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:18-20 shows the Holy Spirit's supernatural work in Jesus’ conception, affirming His divine nature and sinless humanity (Isaiah 7:14; Luke 1:35; John 1:14; Romans 1:3-4; Hebrews 4:15). This underlines the incarnation doctrine.

questions.question: Why was Joseph described as 'a just man' in Matthew 1:19, and how does this characterize his response to Mary's pregnancy?
options: He was righteous and merciful, choosing to protect Mary’s honor quietly
He was harsh and demanded a public trial
He did not believe the angel's message
questions.correctAnswer: He was righteous and merciful, choosing to protect Mary’s honor quietly
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:19 depicts Joseph as righteous, balancing adherence to the law with mercy, choosing a private course to avoid public disgrace (Deuteronomy 22:23-24; Psalm 4:5; Micah 6:8; James 2:13). His character models faithful obedience and compassion.

questions.question: What is the significance of the angel's instruction to Joseph in Matthew 1:21 regarding the name 'Jesus'?
options: Jesus means 'The Lord saves,' indicating His mission to save people from sin
Jesus means 'God with us,' focusing on His divinity
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus means 'The Lord saves,' indicating His mission to save people from sin
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:21 explains that the name Jesus (Yeshua) means 'The Lord saves,' directly revealing His redemptive mission (Isaiah 43:11; Luke 1:31-33; Acts 4:12; Hebrews 9:28; 1 Timothy 1:15). This affirms the doctrine of salvation through Christ.

questions.question: How does Matthew 1:23 link the prophecy of Isaiah to the birth of Jesus, and what theological truth does it reveal?
options: It fulfills Isaiah’s prophecy that a virgin will bear a son named Emmanuel, meaning 'God with us,' revealing Jesus’ divine presence
It denies the virgin birth prophecy, focusing on Joseph's lineage
It claims Jesus is a political leader rather than divine
It focuses on Moses’ prophecy instead
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfills Isaiah’s prophecy that a virgin will bear a son named Emmanuel, meaning 'God with us,' revealing Jesus’ divine presence
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:23 cites Isaiah 7:14, confirming Jesus’ virgin birth and divine identity as God incarnate—Emmanuel means 'God with us' (John 1:14; Hebrews 1:3; Colossians 2:9; Philippians 2:6-7). This underscores the incarnation and God's presence with His people.

questions.question: What does the genealogy in Matthew 1 emphasize about God's providential plan for salvation history?
options: God sovereignly orchestrated history through specific generations leading to Christ
Salvation history is random and unplanned
Jesus’ ancestry is irrelevant to His mission
The genealogy denies Old Testament promises
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly orchestrated history through specific generations leading to Christ
questions.explanation: The genealogy (Matthew 1:2-17) shows God's providence fulfilling promises through Abraham and David’s line, culminating in Jesus (Genesis 12:3; 2 Samuel 7:12-16; Romans 9:5; Galatians 4:4-5; Hebrews 11:39-40). This highlights God's purposeful salvation plan.

questions.question: How does Matthew 1:16 identify Joseph’s relationship to Jesus, and what is the theological implication?
options: Joseph is the husband of Mary, the mother of Jesus, affirming Jesus' legal descent without biological paternity
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph is the husband of Mary, the mother of Jesus, affirming Jesus' legal descent without biological paternity
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:16 clarifies Joseph’s legal fatherhood, important for messianic claims, while the Holy Spirit's role affirms Jesus' divine conception (Luke 1:34-35; Romans 1:3; Hebrews 2:14; Galatians 4:4). This preserves the doctrine of the virgin birth and Jesus' sinless nature.

questions.question: What does Matthew 1:25 reveal about Joseph's relationship with Mary before Jesus' birth, and why is it significant doctrinally?
options: Joseph did not have marital relations with Mary until after Jesus' birth, affirming the virgin birth
Joseph and Mary married after Jesus was born
Joseph rejected Mary before Jesus was born
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph did not have marital relations with Mary until after Jesus' birth, affirming the virgin birth
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:25 confirms Mary’s virginity was intact until Jesus’ birth, supporting the doctrine of the virgin birth and Jesus’ divine origin (Isaiah 7:14; Luke 1:34-35; John 1:14; Galatians 4:4; Hebrews 7:26). This underscores Christ’s sinlessness and deity.

questions.question: How does the inclusion of certain women (e.g., Tamar, Rahab, Ruth, Bathsheba) in the genealogy (Matthew 1:3-6) contribute to biblical theology?
options: It highlights God’s grace and the inclusion of Gentiles and sinners in salvation history
It focuses on patriarchal lineage exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights God’s grace and the inclusion of Gentiles and sinners in salvation history
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:3-6 includes women with complex backgrounds, showing God's redemptive grace extends beyond Israel and purity laws (Genesis 38; Joshua 2; Ruth 1-4; 2 Samuel 11; Galatians 3:28; Ephesians 2:14-18). This anticipates the universal scope of salvation.

questions.question: What is the significance of Matthew 1:11 mentioning the exile to Babylon in the genealogy?
options: It marks a major covenantal and historical turning point in Israel’s history, fulfilled in Christ
It indicates the genealogy ends with the exile
It suggests Jesus was born in Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: It marks a major covenantal and historical turning point in Israel’s history, fulfilled in Christ
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:11 situates Jesus' genealogy within Israel’s history, highlighting the exile as a judgment and restoration theme (2 Kings 25; Jeremiah 29:10; Daniel 9:24-27; Ezra 1:1-4; Luke 1:32-33). Jesus is portrayed as the fulfillment of God's promises after exile.

questions.question: How does Matthew 1:22-23 demonstrate the principle of biblical fulfillment prophecy?
options: It shows Jesus’ birth fulfills Old Testament prophecy about the Messiah
It describes a new prophecy unrelated to the Old Testament
It attributes the prophecy to human invention
questions.correctAnswer: It shows Jesus’ birth fulfills Old Testament prophecy about the Messiah
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:22-23 explicitly connects Jesus’ birth with Isaiah’s prophecy, affirming the reliability of Scripture and divine inspiration (Isaiah 7:14; Luke 1:31; John 5:39; Acts 3:18; 2 Peter 1:20-21). This supports the doctrine of Scripture’s unity and Christ as fulfillment.

questions.question: What doctrinal truth is revealed by the angel addressing Joseph as 'son of David' in Matthew 1:20?
options: It confirms Jesus’ messianic claim as the heir of David’s throne
It refers to Joseph’s priestly role only
questions.correctAnswer: It confirms Jesus’ messianic claim as the heir of David’s throne
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:20 calls Joseph 'son of David,' affirming Jesus’ royal lineage and messianic identity prophesied in the Old Testament (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Jeremiah 23:5; Psalm 89:3-4; Romans 1:3; Revelation 22:16). This is foundational for Christology.

questions.question: What does Matthew 1:24 suggest about Joseph's obedience to divine revelation?
options: Joseph immediately obeyed the angel’s command, modeling faith and submission
Joseph delayed obedience until after Jesus' birth
Joseph doubted and sought another sign
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph immediately obeyed the angel’s command, modeling faith and submission
questions.explanation: Matthew 1:24 records Joseph’s prompt obedience, illustrating trust in God’s revelation (Genesis 22:1-3; Exodus 24:7; Isaiah 6:8; Luke 1:38; Hebrews 11:8). This highlights the virtue of faithful submission to God’s will.

questions.question: Which theological theme is conveyed by the repeated phrase 'begat' in the genealogy of Matthew 1?
options: God’s covenant faithfulness across generations leading to Christ
The importance of biological descent over spiritual identity
The exclusivity of male lineage in salvation
Randomness of human history without divine purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenant faithfulness across generations leading to Christ
questions.explanation: The repeated 'begat' emphasizes God’s covenantal promises honored through successive generations (Genesis 17:7; Exodus 6:2-8; Psalm 105:8-11; Romans 9:4-5; Hebrews 6:13-20). It shows the continuity of God’s plan culminating in Jesus.
